entry.title: New Blog powered by Hexo and Javascript
entry.content:
New year, new blog! This time I tried to find my way around a new blogging engine, similar to Jekyll, but not written in Ruby. I‚Äôm not elitist or anything like that, but I do not particulary like Ruby as a programming language. Don‚Äôt get me wrong - it‚Äôs fine - it‚Äôs just not for me. So - as 2020 went a bit downhill - let‚Äôs try to get 2021 in a better direction.

And yes, I am fully aware it‚Äôs already May and this is my first blog post here, so we‚Äôre off to a great start.

Hexo

What is Hexo? Hexo is basically Jekyll if it were written in Javascript. There may be more to it, but blantly, it boils down to exactly this. You can find Hexo here. What I noticed is, that it seems to be fairly popular in the chinese scene - I choose this theme (pure, by cofess, see bottom left in the menu) as is seemed the most appealing to me. Don‚Äôt hold me to this tho, I might just change the theme one day for no reason. Honestly, nobody cares.

Hexo Themes

This puts me onto my first pain point: Getting started with Hexo is weird. I am used to weird javascript library sans any documentation, but this was something else. It may be just this theme in particular, but many factors played into this. Let me give you a couple of examples:

  • The ‚Äútheme‚Äù, which is basically a glorified EJS template directory, contained hard-coded chinese strings. I managed to replace them with translation strings, which are luckily supported by the framework, but‚Ä¶
  • You need to change the theme (which you actually shouldn‚Äôt) to change strings provided in the languages/ folder - no way to overwrite them from outside
  • There were multiple default settings in the provided ‚Äú_config.yml‚Äù - which is the core configuration file - those were either not taken into account or ignored by the theme - which turns out to have it‚Äôs own _config.yml. You can overwrite values in your own ‚Äú_config.yml‚Äù, but you cannot ‚Äúremove‚Äù those values. Say you want to edit the menu - you can add values, but removing items? Gotta touch the themes/ folder again.
  • The theme contained a couple of errors regarding missing _config.yml values - I added checks to the base-theme so they should now be properly checked - I yet have to create an upstream PR tho.

Thanks to those issues I was actually able to dig right into the center of the framework and dig around the inner workings. It‚Äôs actually pretty fun. For someone less experienced probabbly not as fun, but here be dragons. üêâ

What‚Äôs going on?

I am currently migrating stuff over from the old blog, may take a bit tho. Personal projects now include the following ones right now:

  • Land Crisis (Godot) -> We migrated this project to the Godot Engine now, as we are now fully commited to work forward in the new engine with it - as Unity was too hard to handle for us, for some reason. No idea if it is because of the 2D component or something else, but we had to stop and switch or drop the project.
  • PixelDiorama -> I‚Äôm now part of an upcoming little project called Pixeldiorama, which will contain tutorial videos, pixelart videos, art videos and maybe some projects we are developing.
  • Godot German Community Server -> Earlier this year I was promoted as a moderator in the official german discord server, so I have a couple of tasks to do over there. Nothing earth-shattering, but it keeps me busy from time to time.

Those would be the ‚Äúbig hitters‚Äù right now.

What‚Äôs next?

Well, we‚Äôll see how this goes. First thing‚Äôs first - it‚Äôs ‚ÄúMission May‚Äù which basically means I wrote an spreadsheet where I have to do 1 task per day for at least 1 hour. Right now that didn‚Äôt start off terrible well, but let‚Äôs see how this continues. After that, migrating the old blog posts (incase anyone ever needs them, but mostly myself), and after that, keeping this blog updated with weekly or monthly posts. Not entirely sure how I will handle this, but I will try to keep it at atleast 1 post month.

Got questions? Found some bug? Let me know in the comments below - it requires a GitHub account tho.

entry.title: Export Video with Alpha
entry.content:
A short tutorial on exporting alpha-masked videos in Vegas Pro 15

Prepare

Ensure you have your clip masked properly. Easiest would be to check during Fade-In/Fade-Out by adding a Solid Color Layer and check:

Export

Export Settings:

  • Make sure you select ‚ÄòVideo for Windows‚Äô
  • Select a profile with ‚ÄòYUV‚Äô
  • Select ‚Äòuncompressed‚Äô
  • Check the export alpha checkbox

After export you get a big file. Convert that to something proper with ffmpeg.

Transcode

ffmpeg -i exportFile.avi -c:v libvpx -pix_fmt yuva420p -b:v 5000000 exportFile.webm
